title: Is it possible to find an attorney that might take a student loan case in a chapter 7 bankruptcy for a flat fee?
question: I want to file chapter 7 bankruptcy and want to add my student loan debt into it.
answers:
Bear in mind; you need to do a chapter 7 bankruptcy before doing the student loan case. They are separate cases. As for how much the student loan case costs, You need to think in terms of five figures. Whether your case will be in the low, mid, or high five figures depends on all the factors mentioned by the other answers.

I actually try to propose a flat fee for such cases, but that is only in cases when the issues are pretty narrow.

First off, what type of student loan debt do you have? Federal or private? What is the status and how much is it? What school did you go to? Did you graduate? What has your repayment history been? All of these questions need to be answered before an adversary proceeding is considered. Further, you may have other options. Consult with an attorney who specializes in student loans and bankruptcy

I doubt it for MANY reasons.

First, I have filed over 58 student loan adversary lawsuits and discharged over $ 3 MILLION in student loan debts and all cases posted on my website. Do NOT call me. I only practice in Western Washington.

Second, noone knows how much work there is, how many defendants, if federal or private, how many depositions, if any, the length of trial, whether any appeals and if further appeals to the 9th Circuit even (I have won 3 appellate cases and 2 of my trials upheld by the 9th Circuit ). But a case can also be settled, or settled with some defendants and not others which different options on them.

Third, we dont know if you have federal, and or private loans, which private loans the definition of "student loan" is an entire different definition under recent court cases in the 5th and 10th appellate Courts. There is so much and beyond the scope of AVVO. But do call an experienced attorney who has actually litigated those in your state too. Good luck.
Probably not. Any prospective attorney will probably charge by the hour, because it's almost impossible to predict the amount of work needed to be done.
Generally, student loan debt is non-dischargeable. You need to contact Avvo lawyer DJ Rausa for a consult. He is a student loan specialist. Good luck & God bless.

The fast answer to your question is you might. I'd think it very unlikely, however. No Jinx. Student loan discharge adversary complaints are notoriously hard to prove/be successful. And even so, my understanding is that most student loan entities will likely appeal, which adds to the uncertainty and costs. Due to all of these unknowns, I'm thinking most attorneys would bill hourly with a down payment/retainer to work against. JCC
